content.description: This is an espresso climb - short, full bodied and powerful. Scramble up easy ground to wide ledge then set-up for the route. A low pinch and a dynamic throw to a small crimp start this puppy off and you havent even reached the first bolt yet (stick clip strongly recommended)! Another two dynamic moves brings you pass the second bolt onto better holds above. Place a cam and top out. Rap from large pine tree.
content.protection: Mixed: 2 bolts/no anchors. An easy TR if you are climbing one of the surrounding climbs.
content.location: Beautiful orange face on Right side of Promise block. Starts from ledge.

content.description:
A mix of crack and face climbing make this route a super-pleasure!  Most of the guide books say to start in the middle-to-left part of the face, although it is possible to start in the crack on the right and traverse to the left.  At any rate, a series of thought-provoking and interesting moves lead to a short finger-crack that splits the face.  Embrace the crack with good finger-locks, or go one-hand-in, one-hand-out to reach the top of the crack.  Continue up the face to shuts.

This route is a bit tricky/heady at the start, but can be adequately protected throughout.
content.protection: Nuts and cams to 1".  If you traverse from the right, a 2" piece is helpful in the wide crack.  Bring a handful of slings to avoid rope drag.  Shuts at top.
content.location: The route is on a large face, climber's left from Gemini cracks.  This route is best identified by locating the short crack (10-15 feet) that splits the face.

content.description:
This newly re-bolted sport route is only really worth doing if you are in the area at Bridge. If Promised and the Gemini Cracks lured you out here, well there's a decent sport climb to get your argh on if you are so inclined.

Thin, techy, slopey pockets, and some patina crimps  are the name of the game on this thing. Don't expect chalk so expect to do a bit of route finding to reach the anchors.
content.protection: 5 bolts and bolted anchors with quick snaps. All bolts are in good shape.
content.location: Just around the corner climber's left of Promised

content.description: This is the corner crack on the south side of a protruding section of this cliffline section. Climb up to a lower ledge and chicken-wing your way up the lower, offwidth section (tough crux). Layback and/or jam the steep finger crack to the top.  Some foot placements available by stemming the corner, and a few crimpers to move you upward.
content.protection: Big gear for lower crux & up to 2" for finger-size crack at top.
content.location: Corner crack system on south side of the protruding cliffline section (i.e., steep, square face) of the Promised Area.

content.description: If anyone has information about this route being done previously, please let me know. Could likely be an obscurity forgotten over time or just simply undocumented. Regardless, it's a very fun route and would make a great warmup for the rest of the wall. Climbs some awesome features!
content.protection: Standard trad rack. No anchor. Plenty of options for trees. No big gear necessary.
content.location: This route climbs the obvious, wide, water-grooved crack to the right of Blackberry Blossom. Once the crack ends, step right and climb the features up the face aiming for the flake up high until you can top it out.

content.description: Start on my wife is a dog, but at the horizontal break halfway up, traverse right around the arete and climb the sool overhanging flake to the top of the Berlin Wall. Super rad, but dock a star for the shared start and tedious wandering about to get to the money
content.location: start on My Wife is a Dog

content.description: If this sport climb got some TLC and a set of anchors it would be a real draw for the area. Until then either anchor from trees, walk-off or bring a leave it to lower from the last bolt.
content.location: Start just right of arête and traverse left to first bolt. Continue up on face using good edges and finish on bulge above.

content.description: A chimney, crack, face and arête all in one climb  this has it all! Shimmy pass the short chimney to the wide ledge twenty feet up then step five feet left to a crack or continue straight up on Highlander (5.10c).  Follow crack to face and then finish on arête near top.
content.location: Start in obvious chimney Left of Promise (5.10b) right where the access trail comes up from the road.

content.description: Great route! Challenging direct start (best), but also possible to traverse in from left to ledge. Fairly sustained finger crack, awkward flared pod (crux). Not many rests.
content.protection: Good pro. Small-medium nuts, cams, etc. Shuts.
content.location: South Bridge Wall - left of Your Mother, Where Real Men Dare, Maranatha, Beginners Only....keep walking left along wall until two obvious face cracks appear together. Of the two (twin Gemini Cracks), this is the right one.

content.description: This routes looks intimidating compared to Gemini Right, but excellent protection and fun moves makes this a must-do. In my mind, there are two distinct cruxes, one down low, about 15 feet off the deck, and the second at the main bulge about 2/3 of the way up. The first crux is a delicate, balancy move, and the second is more mental as you surmount the bulge.
content.protection: Excellent protection.  Mostly small-mid size cams/nuts, but you may want a 2 or 3 up top, as I recall.  Shuts at top, shared with Gemini Right.
content.location: Just left of Gemini Right.  Obvious thin finger-crack.

content.description: Short and sweet, Esse Crack is definitely worth checking out.  At only about 40 feet long, this S-shaped finger crack has a variety of entertaining moves and only a moderately difficult 10c.  The crux is probably up towards the top, where the feet get thin and the crack can be a bit damp at times.
content.protection: Great protection, small-mid cams/nuts.  Anchor at top is large tree - bring something to extend 10-15 feet if you plan to top-rope.  Possible to walk off to left, but be careful.
content.location: Just around the corner from 'Promised', and, well, in a corner!  Starts below a low roof.  Look for the S-shaped finger crack.  Nice and tucked away on those crowded bridge days.

content.description:
Smear and frog your way up through 2 distinct cruxes. Bring knee & elbow pads.

"The big chimney behind the Promised wall will get you ready for the Texas Flake pitch on El Cap."

Mike Williams - New River Rock Volume 1
content.protection: No fixed anchor. Rap off of the bolted anchor for Happy Head.
content.location: Behind the Promised wall. Obvious chimney.

content.description: Boulder up the start of Butter Face getting good gear in both horizontals, extend to reduce drag around the corner. From the corner stance traverse out right on the horizontal and mantle the ledge to establish on Happy Head.  Finish up Happy Head.
content.protection: Shares the bolt anchor with Happy Head
content.location: A left entry into Happy Head that starts just around the corner.  Shares the start of Butter Face and then links into Happy Head at the arête.
